definition[0]: showing a lack of good sense or good judgment
example[1]: That was a stupid thing to say.
example[2]: I can’t believe Kate was stupid enough to get involved in this.
example[3]: It was stupid of me to lose my temper.
definition[1]: having a low level of intelligence, so that you have difficulty learning or understanding things
example[6]: I couldn’t do it, and it made me feel stupid.
definition[2]: used when you are talking about something or someone that makes you annoyed or impatient
example[7]: I can’t get this stupid radio to work.
example[8]: What is that stupid idiot doing?
definition[3]: showing a total lack of good sense or good judgment. Stupid  sounds very strong and is often used when you are annoyed or strongly criticizing someone’s behaviour
example[9]: I wish you’d stop asking stupid questions.
example[10]: It was stupid of me to leave the door unlocked.
example[11]: Well, if you’re stupid enough to skate on the lake, you deserve to fall in.
definition[4]: doing or saying things that are not sensible or serious, and that may make you feel embarrassed later. Silly sounds much gentler than stupid
example[13]: Don’t be so silly! There’s nothing wrong with you.
example[14]: I think you’re silly to worry so much about your hair.
definition[5]: not sensible, often in a way that is also amusing
example[15]: Is this another of your daft ideas?
example[16]: Don’t be daft! Of course you’re not too old to go clubbing.
example[18]: He was dumb enough to believe her.
example[19]: Oh, I just did the dumbest thing back there, I forgot my purse.
definition[6]: stupid. Foolish sounds rather formal and is used mainly in written English. The usual words to use in everyday English are silly or stupid
example[20]: It was a foolish thing to say.
example[21]: They did not want to look foolish.
example[22]: It was all a foolish dream.
example[23]: I think the board of directors made a foolish choice that it will later regret.
definition[7]: done without thinking carefully enough about the possible disadvantages that may result
example[24]: She knew the marriage was unwise.
example[26]: It would be very unwise to speculate.
definition[8]: used when you think that what someone is planning or suggesting is certain to fail, but you do not want to say directly that they are behaving in a stupid way
example[27]: The leader of the opposition described it as ‘a brave decision.’
example[28]: I think he’s being very brave.
definition[9]: not at all sensible or reasonable – used when you are very surprised by someone’s behaviour or what they have said
example[29]: Ian’s got some crazy plan to drive across Africa.
example[30]: She looked at me as if I was crazy!
example[31]: You’re crazy to think of hitch-hiking on your own.
example[32]: You look ridiculous in that hat.
example[33]: Some people spend a ridiculous amount of money on cars.
example[34]: It’s absolutely ridiculous to suggest that he would do something like that.
definition[11]: extremely stupid – used especially when an idea or situation seems strange or illogical
example[35]: How can a return ticket cost less than a single? It’s totally absurd!
example[37]: Some of the objections to the theory are simply absurd.
definition[12]: so stupid that you cannot believe someone is telling the truth or being serious
example[40]: It would be laughable if it wasn’t so serious.
definition[13]: an insulting way of talking to someone who you think is being stupid
example[41]: No, stupid, don’t do it like that!
